reviewText:
A cute Ys-style game from Falcom, originally released for PC in 2004 and ported to the PSP in 2007. The game's environments and BGM are quite relaxing, as you wander about the town, helping characters solve their problems. The voice dub is competent, if goofy in a way, and the characters are very well-drawn and animated. The art is very well done. Almost all of the various headgear and costumes you acquire along the way fit Parin rather nicely.

There is a lot of attention to detail in this game. Stand Parin the protagonist next to a character dancing to his boombox and she will join right in. Characters go about their lives in town and might wander in and out of different buildings if you are looking for them. Parin in particular is full of personality, from the way she acts and how she responds to other characters.

Gameplay-wise, combat is smooth, and the invincibility frames you get are very generous. It's not nearly as difficult as Ys, but some opponents are notably tougher than the rest though, otherwise this is a very child-friendly game. There are plenty of secrets to find and things to unlock. Truly mastering a stage would mean getting S triple + rank, so there is plenty to do.

Criticisms incude: keyboard key-binding options are not the best and camera control with a controller is non-existent. The option for Japanese audio would have been nice, but Mastiff (the localization company) is looking into both of these at time of writing. The higher difficulty levels also need to be unlocked first.

Games with unadulterated charm like these are rare these days, so give it a whirl if you like the genre.

The music is pretty good and worth mentioning as well, although I recommend turning the BG music down a bit in the pre-game config.

This game is actually pretty remeniscent of MegaMan Legends, which is one of my all time favorite games. It doesn't QUITE stand up to that, but it does evoke similar memories.

Not bad for the price, I recommend it if you're looking for a good Japanese action-adventure!

reviewText:
Overall I would recommend this game. At $10 it's really hard not to; there are many games released nowadays without half the charm and without much of the same level content for a far higher price. Gurumin is not without its flaws, but I don't think the flaws are significant enough to outweigh the positives.

While the game is classified here as an Action RPG, I would argue against the RPG part of that. Is an RPG a game where your choices as your character define the world and set you on different story paths? This game doesn't do that (there are two endings available, but it's based on percentage of completion and not any choices made throughout the story, because there are none). Is it being able to assign points to various attributes like Strength, Charisma, etc.? This game doesn't do that; in fact, the only direct statistical upgrades for your character are health point increases after bosses, similar to what you would find in a Legend of Zelda title. What the game DOES have is an impressive array of hats that alter various aspects of your character (more damaging attacks, less damage taken, show treasure chests on the minimap, etc.), but Team Fortress 2 has that and I wouldn't classify that as an RPG either. I can't see ANY mention of the musical side of this game ANYWHERE on the Steam page which is very strange; I'd classify this game as a Musical Action game, if that's even a genre that exists.

The game places a fairly high priority in platforming, especially later in the game, and that is I think Gurumin's greatest weakness. Parin's jumps are a little hard to control, and her shadow is often not pronounced enough to tell exactly where she is located over sometimes excessively small platforms. The spastic camera, which refuses to stay put and constantly tries to center itself behind Parin, certainly doesn't help matters. Why am I given a button to immediately center the camera behind Parin if the game does this automatically every time I start to move? If I move the camera, I want it in that position until I say otherwise; several of the game's tricky jumps would be made vastly more simple if only I could set the camera at Parin's side and leave it there until after the platforming section, but if this option is available then I never found it. In the end I usually resigned myself to platforming relying entirely on the minimap; at least with the minimap there was no ambiguity as to whether I was over a platform or not.

Combat, however, is enjoyable, even if it is a bit easy (note that I have only beaten the game on Normal, and that higher difficulties might actually be...difficult). The next few sections are going to be talking about combat since it has some nuances. Parin has a standard neutral attack string and a variation if you hold in a direction while attacking, but you probably won't often be using those. Parin's dodge is extremely long and forgiving, and she gets three of them in a row; I never timed it but it has to be at least 3 full seconds of invincibility which is pretty insane in a game like this. Beyond that, one of the first special attacks you get is an attack after the dodge, and you're ALSO invincible during that attack animation, which at higher ranks adds another second and a half or so. There's little reason not to simply spam this one special technique over and over until everything in the room is dead considering that the attack itself is extremely damaging and reaches over a very wide area. Certain enemies have shields or armor on and are impervious to attack, so the armor needs to be removed by utilizing Parin's charged drill attack (this seems to be its only purpose, as the damage the charged drill attack does is pathetic even compared to normal attacks), but after that you're free to attack in whatever way you wish. The game does add in elemental effects (fire, lightning, and ice) that can be changed at a whim. Fire burns enemies and causes damage (a fairly small amount) over time, lightning slows and paralyzes enemies, and ice freezes them in place. There is also a system in place where certain enemies take more or less damage from certain elements, but at least on Normal mode this is easily ignored and the damage reduction for using the wrong element is fairly insignificant. Elemental attacks are also used in several of the game's puzzles. The only non-special attack that I used often is her homing jump attack, which is not only very useful for attacking flying enemies but is also extremely accurate (fittingly enough) and does fairly high damage. It is also, coincidentally, absolutely vital for some minigames.

One thing to note is that all special attacks in this game are performed the exact same way; rotate the character either clockwise or counterclockwise and then attack.  Doing it without dodging/jumping performs a 360 spin, doing it during a dodge performs a projectile attack (this is the room cleaner I mentioned above), and doing it during a jump performs a slam. I used a PS2-type controller, and the game is very forgiving with its detection of turns. It is, in fact, TOO forgiving, and I can't count the number of times I was jumping during platforming to attack an enemy and found myself plummeting straight into an abyss.

The last thing I have to talk about concerning combat is the drill meter. Parin uses a drill as her weapon. The drill has 4 levels (the game only counts 3 but I'll explain why I say it has 4). The higher the level of the drill, the more damage it does (some special attacks also change animations depending on its level). When the bar is filled to max you get a projectile attack every time you swing the drill; the game counts this as part of the 3rd drill level but since it's only actually available with a FILLED 3rd level and not just IN the 3rd level I count it as its own level. Now, how do you increase the drill level? The standard way is to get critical hits, and this is where the music minigame comes into play. It's actually so important a consideration in the game that I'm surprised Gurumin isn't called a Music Action game. At the top of the screen is a bar that acts as a metronome for the current music; if you time your strikes with the metronome you get critical hits, and every 100 critical hits gives you a drill level. There are also items and certain areas within stages you can use to increase your drill level, but both of these are fairly rare and for the most part you'll be relying on critical hits. This is why I say its strange the musical side of the game is so underplayed on the Steam store page.

As for music and sound...music is good. I can't think of a single song I disliked and there were several I would actually nod my head to as they played. As fits the game most of them are fast-paced and quite a few are cheery (sometimes a little overly cheery) but they didn't grate on my nerves. The sound effects are fairly simplistic, but it isn't as though this is a complicated, deep game or story so it fits the tone well. What I WILL complain about is the voice acting. It's sub-par to downright awful all across the board. I'm running out of space but suffice it to say that I didn't like anyone.

The story is cookie-cutter and saccharine (it involves giving monsters furniture to make them happy so that their happiness drives away the darkness. No, I am not oversimplifying it), and though I rolled my eyes during much of it I never hated it. Characterization is rather sparse, but then I don't think anyone came into this game expecting Catcher in the Rye.

I spent a fair amount of time complaining during this review, but the main thing to take away from this is that while the combat was simple I enjoyed it. reviewText:
I want to start off saying this isn't a bad game. The reason why I leave this game a negative review is because the description on the game's page is misleading. The game advertises itself as have 35+ hours of gameplay; however, this is incorrect. On average, it takes maybe 11 hours to beat the game. I looked up the game on the HowLongtoBeat website and it is listed as 9-11 hours and 17 hours for completionists, meaning that even for people who want to experience all of the content in the game, it only takes them 17 hours on average, which is half the amount of time that the game makers advertise. One of the reasons I originally purchased this game was because I believed I'd be getting a decent game length out of it, and I didn't. I don't have anything against shorter games, but it was a game I had been expecting to put more time into because of this advertisement.

I will go over the game's pros and cons now.

Pros:
-Decent platforming game with unique levels
-Good for people who like to collect items or beat their own high scores/times
-Cute character designs
-Catchy music
-Wearing items changes the costume on the character
-Runs well even on non-gaming pcs and laptops

Cons:
-Game can be beaten in 9-17 hours on average (not as advertised 35+)
-Characters are not fleshed out enough
-Unlocking areas or progressing the story is sometimes extremely obscure without a guide
-There is an adult character that tries to go on dates with the little girls in the game and it is passed off like a silly joke. This part particularly irked me because the game is otherwise appropriate for kids to play and yet it normalizes a grown adult trying to pursue romantic relationships with prepubescent girls. This is another reason why I choose not to recommend the game, but the main reason is the false advertisement.

reviewText:
TL;DR I got the game for free and I feel robbed, it's buggy and Mastiff should be ashamed.

Thoughts:
Great game, I love Falcom and their games, but Mastiff's effort in the publishing of Gurumin is non-existent.
The game does have a few faults by default, one being the overly sensitive input for performing special moves (You'll sometimes do spin attacks by turning only a half circle before attacking). People who use controllers (myself included) may also find the analogue input to be overly sensitive as well, which just comes down to needing to adjust the deadzone of your controller.

Now for the things that Mastiff did wrong:
As you get past the halfway point you'll soon notice several lines of dialogue being unacceptably incomplete.

A couple of steam achievements do not unlock properly and requires you to beat the final boss and watch the whole ending TWICE per difficulty to unlock both, that is if you actually made a save before a certain point in the game, otherwise you'll have to replay the whole game to unlock the other achievement.

The unlockable Item List does not update properly and is showing a majority of blanks despite having beaten the game to 100% twice.

The PSP version (Also published by Mastiff) has content which this version does not, including:
At least 5 extra costumes.
Original Japanese voice line option (Available on the PC version through manually downloading and overwriting audio files with original Jap audio, search Steam threads if you're interested)
Skippable cutscenes.


Conclusion:
I would've recommended this game outright simply because it's another great Falcom game, but this version is an example of publishing done wrong, Mastiff has put in minimal effort to properly bring a good product to Steam.
If this had been published by XSEED we would've had a version of the game with full uncensored content for sure and without any bugs.

Pierre and Doug are voiced by Robin Atkin Downes, aka The Medic and Dee Bradley Baker, most known for voicing many Spongebob characters is in this too!)

-A storyline that at times can be serious, but most of the time doesn't take itself seriously and has many light-hearted elements.

-An absolutely awesome and always upbeat and rocking soundtrack!

-Simple and intuitive controls (not to mention fluid)

-Has RPG elements but for those who are new to games with RPG elements, this game simplifies them, saving you the stress of understanding them.

-A ultra-simple equip mechanic, just put on a different piece of headgear on the fly to use its attributes to turn the tide in battle! (PLUS headgear can be further upgraded, gaining new perks and even strengthening its current attributes!)

-LOTS of collectibles and extras, perfect for the gamers who like to collect everything and for completionists!

-This game may have linear progression, but 100% of the time it encourages players to explore the areas (hidden areas, breakable walls) and are rewarded for their curiosity for going out of the beaten path.

-A unique lineup of enemies that have the players think of which strategies and/or weaknesses to use on them.

-Formidable boss battles that have patterns players must adapt to (it's more fun to experiment methods of defeating the bosses everytime in newer, faster, and more efficient ways!)

reviewText: Gurumin is an action RPG by Falcom featuring a young girl named Parin who must go on an adventure to save the monster world.  As Parin you will make many monster friends while being tasked with helping them fix their world by tracking down items in all sorts of interesting environments.  The story is heartwarming in a childlike way as both your monster friends and bad guys all have interesting personalities and the well written script and professional voice acting really helps bring them to life.  Along the way you will bash evil monsters with an array of combat moves that you can unlock with money you find in each level area.  The combat is a combination of joystick twirling and timed button pressing, nothing revolutionary but it works well.  There are also platforming elements that you will use to navigate the terrain and search for hidden treasure, healing items and head pieces (hats, ribbons, etc) that you can equip to power Parin up in different ways.    Graphically Gurumin is somewhat blocky and basic, but it’s very colorful and each area you explore is filled with interesting inhabitants that evolve as you explore further, helping to reduce the repetition that often accompanies action RPG’s.  Playing thru Gurumin is like exploring a new park as a child who has a vivid  imagination; discovering monsters, avoiding the lava and having a grand old time in an adventure that is light and fun with enough of a gaming challenge to feel satisfying.  Recommended for the young at heart, plays well with a game pad too.

Finally reached the US on PC, Gurumin is an interesting action platformer with many puzzles involving the use of the main weapon of the game: a Drill. Finding a crack in the ground? use your drill. You might find a secret.

The game's story is nothing to get too excited about, but it pulls it off in this nice anime feel, you can't help but enjoy it at times.

I originally learned of this game from a japanese imported PSP demo. I knew I found something special back then, and I'm very happy to see the US finally getting an official PC release.

Gurumin is an action platformer developed by Falcom in 2003.   The project was helmed by the same group who made Zwei but is about a girl who uses a drill to defeat enemies and dig through structures instead of using a partner to shoot magic and relies on eating to boost stats.   This title was also made when Nihon Falcom was sorta in a rut and didn't find financial success to run on until Sora no Kiseki Second Chapter. reviewText:
A simple action-adventure (with a limited RPG elements) with okay graphics, decent animations/sound, and a story from a child's POV. Controls are usually fine, and the game engine physics allows you to kinda wallrun if you jump towards a wall, which looks pretty funny. You can manually resize the game window, which is pretty handy.

Dungeons are fun enough to run through, but don't expect too many innovations- it sticks to a very basic formula. You go room by room, killing all enemies, breaking all pots, opening all chests, and doing simple puzzles. At the end of a dungeon, you get one item to return to the monster village (which then unlocks more dungeons). You might even notice it reuses rooms a couple times in different dungeons with a little twist (like flipped).

There are several minigames of varying quality. The most annoying is the 3v3 football/soccer one in which you can't control/dribble the ball, only hit it with attacks. If you try to play it like a normal sports game you'll be frustrated since most likely you'll never score a goal yourself. Just do locked-on jump attacks on the ball and it'll automatically hit it towards the enemy goal instead of straight ahead. You can just play defense and your AI ally will eventually get enough goals in.

Enemies aren't too hard, and you're free to switch between the three elements (for enemy weaknesses) and your head gear (for your resistances) in combat to finish them quickly. Bosses are pretty straightforward and in normal difficulty can be brute forced with healing items if you just want to run up and slash.

If you enjoy this basic formula, a childlike/innocent story, and the visuals this game might be for you. Otherwise, there are other action-RPGs that might be more tailored to your tastes.

MUH DRILLZ!

I'll get straight to the point: this game will definitely drill its way into your heart. *pause for laughter or groans*

*ahem* now that I have you either groaning from the pun or laughing your ♥♥♥ off, I'll start the real review.

This game comes to steam years later from the initial release in japan back in 2004, which got ported to PSP in June of 2006, made a north american appearance in 2007, and got an original PC release worldwide on steam.  From my point of view, everything about this game is great, with just a few minor complaints I have, which I will get to in this review.

Graphics: 9/10 - The graphics remind me of early playstation games such as Brave Fencer Musashi.  They get the job done, vibrant, and great use of color.  You can also tell it makes great use of cell-shading, but the characters do tend to look a little too simplistic.  Overall, however, this game looks great.

Gameplay: 9.5/10 - The game plays very well, and that's as much as I can say about it right now as I've only just started playing this game.  I will definitely update when the time comes, but one minor complaint: so far, I haven't really run into any boss fights. EDIT: Just ran into my first boss fight, and lemmie tell ya, they can really drill it to ya -pause again for laughs or groans-.  They're challenging, but fair.  It at least gives you time to use healing items and not have them clobber you as you do so.  Overall, the boss fights are great and vibrant.

Controls: 8/10 - Here's where I have to make a few complaints about controls here.  Some of the moves aren't very clear on what to do, especially if you're using a gamepad (or xbox 360/XBOne controller) for control.  The instructions are strictly PC oriented with no mention of what to do with the gamepad.  I would complain about it more, if it weren't for the fact that you learn pretty quickly what buttons do what move, so it's no big issue and the controls can be customized*.
However, the controls do the job well, either way.  The jump controls are interesting, but can get a little frustrating, especially having to make platform jumps.  Fortunately, the shadow effects will help you, and you can angle the camera any way you please (right stick for xbox 360 controllers).  The inclusion of timed hits to the beat of the music with the beat bar displayed on screen is a wonderful addition.  If you've mastered Crypt of the Necrodancer, you'll definitely find that getting critical hits via the beat of the music to be very easy and fun.

Sound: 9/10 - The music, even though you can tell it's synthesizer, is VERY well done.  The english voice acting is a bit cheesy, but works anyways.  The music is upbeat and well composed, in my opinion.  You'll need to get that tempo down if you want to do critical hit damage, but the timing of each beat is precise and works very well.

Overall: 9.25/10 - This game is definitely a title for platform gamers to really dig into -pause for groans or laughter-.  Hopefully, we'll see some patches released to fix some of the issues, but overall, I recommend this game for anyone who loves a good platform game.

reviewText:
Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure, developed by Nihon Falcom, is a HD re-release of the 2004 Japan-only PC game, with Gurumin last seeing English storefronts on the PSP in 2007.

As a result, as well as running on just about anything, Gurumin serves as a time-capsule of videogames before contemporary design trends. Aesthetically, it's an adorable adventure game that resembles games like Blinx the Time Sweeper, 40 Winks, Ape Escape or just about any simple platformer with action elements from the fifth generation that you can think of.

Layout-wise, it's exactly what you'd think. There's about 25 levels, each 5-15 minutes long, several different minigames, a secret boss and more than enough regular bosses to keep you satiated. The plot is simple, charming, and ends on as sickening a saccharine note as you could possibly want, though not before a satisfying one-on-one beatdown to decide the world's fate. The game goes out of its way to avoid surprising you - it's a comforting, easing experience first and foremost, with enough enthusiasm and charisma for its own existence to keep you playing and wanting more.

There are other benefits from refusing to evolve into a world of DLC and microtransactions. From the secret unlockables (which I won't spoil, else they wouldn't be secrets) to the plethora of regular unlockables, to the surprising (and punishing!) extra difficulty modes - this is a game from before the era of DLC nickel and diming you on extra content that used to be a joy to unlock.

reviewText:
Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure, developed by Nihon Falcom, is a HD re-release of the 2004 Japan-only PC game, with Gurumin last seeing English storefronts on the PSP in 2007.

As a result, as well as running on just about anything, Gurumin serves as a time-capsule of videogames before contemporary design trends. Aesthetically, it's an adorable adventure game that resembles games like Blinx the Time Sweeper, 40 Winks, Ape Escape or just about any simple platformer with action elements from the fifth generation that you can think of.

Layout-wise, it's exactly what you'd think. There's about 25 levels, each 5-15 minutes long, several different minigames, a secret boss and more than enough regular bosses to keep you satiated. The plot is simple, charming, and ends on as sickening a saccharine note as you could possibly want, though not before a satisfying one-on-one beatdown to decide the world's fate. The game goes out of its way to avoid surprising you - it's a comforting, easing experience first and foremost, with enough enthusiasm and charisma for its own existence to keep you playing and wanting more.

There are other benefits from refusing to evolve into a world of DLC and microtransactions. reviewText:
This is a surprisingly fun game, I say surprising as my initial reaction was a little lukewarm but the more I played the more the overall charm of the game won me over. You play Parin a spunky young girl who has come to stay with her grandfather while her parents are away. It quickly becomes apparent that there isn't much to do in the mining town where he lives, but Parin is soon sucked into an adventure to rescue a group of friendly monsters. The game is fairly light plotwise but its enough to drive things forward and the dialogue is often funny. The games real draw is the action packed game play that requires good use of your drill and special moves to beat the crap out of a variety of foes. It features an interesting critical hit system that is linked to the games music, get the timing right and you will do extra damage. There are also some light platforming and puzzle solving elements. This is an update of an older game and it shows in the textures which are sometimes muddy and lack detail, overall though the art design is very good and Parin herself is well animated with a variety of expressions and idle animations that bring her to life. Bear with the slightly rough start and you will be rewarded with a game that is deeper than it first appears.

Pros:
Charm in spades
Amusing dialogue
Fun action RPG-lite gameplay
Some good music
Good art design

Cons:
Dated textures
Camera can be touchy in confined spaces

7.5 out of 10 and well worth the $10 entry fee.
